Hunt]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1861|8|8|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Keokuk, Iowa|Keokuk]], [[Iowa]], [[United States]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1905|12|30|1861|8|8}} |death_place = [[Caldwell, Idaho|Caldwell]], [[Idaho]] |spouse = Belle Keppel Steunenberg |profession = [[Newspaper]] [[Publisher]], [[Politician]] |residence = [[Caldwell, Idaho|Caldwell]] |religion = [[Christianity|Christian]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]], [[Populist Party (United States)|Populist]] }} '''Frank Steunenberg''' (August 8, 1861{{ndash}} December 30, 1905) was the [[List of Governors of Idaho|fourth Governor]] of the [[U.S. state|State]] of [[Idaho]], serving from 1897 until 1901. He is perhaps best known for his 1905 [[assassination]] by one-time union member [[Albert Horsley|Harry Orchard]], who was also a paid informant for the [[Cripple Creek, Colorado|Cripple Creek]] [[Mine Owners' Association]].Roughneck, The Life and Times of Big Bill Haywood, Peter Carlson, 1983, page 119. Orchard attempted to implicate leaders of the radical [[Western Federation of Miners]] in the assassination. The labor leaders were found not guiltyRoughneck, The Life and Times of Big Bill Haywood, Peter Carlson, 1983, page 135. in two trials,The Autobiography of Big Bill Haywood, William Dudley Haywood, 1929, page 224 ppbk. but Orchard spent the rest of his life in prison. ==Early career== Born in [[Keokuk, Iowa|Keokuk]], [[Iowa]], Steunenberg attended [[Iowa State University|Iowa State College]] at [[Ames, Iowa|Ames]] and then went on to become a printer's apprentice and publisher. In 1881 he was hired by the ''[[Des Moines Register]]'' in [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]]. Steunenberg later published a newspaper in [[Knoxville, Iowa|Knoxville]] until 1886, when he moved west and settled in [[Caldwell, Idaho]], where he joined his brother in taking over the ''[[The Idaho Press-Tribune|Caldwell Tribune]]'' for six years.Idaho State Historical Society Public Archives Research Library. http://www.idahohistory.net/Reference%20Series/0402.pdf In Caldwell Steunenberg became active in politics and was elected to the first Idaho Legislature in 1890 at age 29 as a [[Electoral fusion|fusion]] candidate, endorsed by both the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] and [[Populist Party (United States)|Populist]] Parties. ==Governor== With [[labor union]] support, in 1896 Steunenberg was nominated as both the Democratic and Populist candidate for [[Governor of Idaho|governor]]. He won the November election and became the first non-[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] elected to that office and was re-elected to second two-year term in 1898. Steunenberg served during a period of considerable labor unrest, particularly in the mining industry in [[Idaho Panhandle|northern]] Idaho. As a result, many corporations, fearing that Steunenberg's government would not support them if there was a [[Strike action|strike]], increased their wages for workers. The [[Bunker Hill Mining Company]], however, did not. In April 1899 striking members of the [[Western Federation of Miners]] destroyed the company's mill at [[Wardner, Idaho|Wardner]]. In response Steunenberg declared [[martial law]] and asked [[President of the United States|President]] [[William McKinley]] to send federal troops to quell the unrest. (''See also: [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor confrontation of 1899]].'') This action was seen as a betrayal by Steunenberg's union supporters. Martial law remained in place through the end of his term, and Steunenberg did not seek a third term in 1900. ==Assassination== {{see also|James McParland}} [[File:Boise-capitol.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Statue of Governor Steunenberg, opposite of the front steps of the [[Idaho State Capitol]]]] Four years after he left office, Steunenberg was killed outside his house in Caldwell by a bomb rigged to the front gate. [[Harry Orchard]] was arrested shortly after for the assassination, and the investigation was conducted by [[Pinkerton National Detective Agency|Pinkerton]] agent [[James McParland]]. With the promise of a lighter sentence, McParland compelled Orchard to write a confession in which he implicated [[Bill Haywood|"Big Bill" Haywood]], general secretary of the Western Federation of Miners, [[Charles Moyer]], president of the Western Federation of Miners, and [[George Pettibone]], a labor activist who had a prior conviction related to an [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor strike of 1892|1892 dispute]] in [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho|Coeur d'Alene]], as co-conspirators. McParland arrested the three in [[Colorado]] in February 1906. The nationally publicized trial took place in [[Boise, Idaho|Boise]] in 1907 and included [[United States Senator|Senator]] [[William Borah]] for the prosecution and [[Clarence Darrow]] for the defense. There was a lack of evidence in a case that was supported only by Orchard's testimony. Darrow, a lawyer who specialized in defending trade union leaders, won an [[acquittal]] for Haywood. Pettibone was defended in a separate trial by [[Orrin N. Hilton|Judge Hilton]] of [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] and was also acquitted, and charges were dropped against Moyer.The Autobiography of Big Bil Haywood, William Dudley Haywood, 1929, page 224 ppbk.
